nodes.text: A decision tree based machine learning model can classify and predict diabetes from patient data
We used the Pima Indians Diabetes dataset containing 768 patient instances and 9 attributes to develop the model
Data preprocessing removed rows with zero values in BloodPressure, BMI, and Glucose because zeros are considered erroneous
A binary decision tree classifier was implemented in Python using Pandas and scikit-learn and visualized; training/testing splits were varied (70/30, 50/50, 30/70)
Decision tree node splitting used information gain based on measures of heterogeneity: entropy, Gini index, and classification error as described
Experiment 1 with 70% training and 30% testing produced classification results and a rendered decision tree (figures reported)
Experiment 2 with 50% training and 50% testing produced classification results and a rendered decision tree (figures reported)
Experiment 3 with 30% training and 70% testing produced classification results and a rendered decision tree (figures reported)
The best observed accuracy among tested splits was 0.71 for the 50% training / 50% testing split
Model evaluation included accuracy estimate, classification report, and confusion matrix as implemented after prediction
There are outliers and erroneous zero values in some dataset columns, indicating data quality issues that required cleaning
Conclusion: Decision tree analysis is a suitable predictive modeling tool for diabetes classification, offering fast learning, intuitive rules, nonparametric modeling and competitive accuracy
Practical caveat: system outputs require a doctor consultation and more accurate diagnosis after model results because some dataset features may not be available to users
Claim: Allocating more data to training generally improves accuracy estimates, but in these experiments the 50/50 split gave the best observed accuracy
Context: Diabetes prevalence has risen globally and accurate diagnostic tools are needed; prior ML methods (naive Bayes, SVM) reported lower or limited factor use
